summary.text: Patterns are the building blocks of Zen. They are used to generate patterns of values in interesting, concise ways.
Shorthand aliases for pattern methods.

content.text:
```ts
qm: 'qmeasurement',
qms: 'qmeasurements',
qpb: 'qprobability',
qpbs: 'qprobabilities',
qph: 'qphase',
qphs: 'qphases',
qr: 'qresult',
```

content.text:
```ts
s0.e.bin('1111') // output depends on the number of division per cycle / canvas. If 16, returns 1 every 4 divisions, 0 otherwise
```

Convert a number to binary string, then passes it to .bin().

content.text:
```ts
s0.n.ntbin(9, 8) // 9 in binary is 1001, padded out to 8 digits. Passes 00001001 to .bin()
```

A Stream is a musical layer. You can think of it as a track in a DAW, or a channel in a mixer.
It can be used to control multiple instruments, effects, and routing.
Streams are available within Zen as

The Wire class represents a single wire in a quantum circuit. They are represented in Zen as q0, q1, q2, etc. 
It uses the Quantum Circuit package to implement quantum gates. 
Some gates are documented here. See https://www.npmjs.com/package/quantum-circuit#implemented-gates for a list of all implemented gates.
Toffoli gate, or CCNOT gate
index or array of indexes
number of columns to skip
Controlled NOT gate, or CNOT gate

readme.text:
# Zen

Zen is a live coding environment for the browser, with an emphasis on the use of quantum algorithms for music generation. You can use it at [https://zen.cephasteom.co.uk/](https://zen.cephasteom.co.uk/) or download a version for desktop at [https://github.com/cephasteom/zen-electron](https://github.com/cephasteom/zen-electron).

This project was built with, amongst other things, SvelteKit.

## Developing

Install dependencies with

```bash
npm run dev

# or start the server and open the app in a new browser tab
npm run dev -- --open
```

## Building

To create a production version of the app:
You can preview the production build with

.

## Docs
We use TSDocs to generate documentation for all Zen classes and synths. These generate each time you run a build. If you want to refresh them manually see the scripts in
